msItem.title: The Hymns of Severus, John bar Aphtūnāyā, etc.
msItem.finalRubric: ܫ̣ܠܡ ܠܡܟ̣ܬܒ ܡ̈ܥܢܝܬܐ ܕܩܕܝܫܐ ܡܪܝ ܣܐܘܪܐ ܦܛܪܝܪܟܐ

msItem.title: Before the lesson from the Gospel
After the lesson from the Gospel
The Commemorations of Saints, Martyrs, and Fathers.
The entrance of the holy Eucharist
On a woman who was converted from the Arian heresy
The Consecration of a church or of an altar
Hymns entitled "praises," to be used on different occasions, at the celebration of the holy Eucharist
msItem.rubric: ܬܘܒ ܛܟ̣ܣܐ ܕܫܘ̈ܒܚܐ ܕܝܠܗ ܕܩܕܝܫܐ ܡܪܝ ܣܐܘܪܐ

item.p: Vellum, about 5 3/8 in. by 4, consisting of 151 leaves, a few of which are much stained and torn, especially foll. 1, 117, 120, 126, 145, and 151. The quires, signed with letters, were probably 18 in number, of which the first and last are missing. The number of lines in each page varies from 13 to 26. From fol. 117 onwards, this manuscript contains numerous palimpsest leaves, several of which belong to the rare class of double palimpsests. They appear to have been taken from no less than five manuscripts (see Add. 17,136, foll. 117 and 126, upper text 1 , Add. 17,136, foll. 117 and 126, lower text , Add. 17,136, foll. 120, 137, and 139, upper text 1 , Add. 17,136, foll. 120, 137, and 139, lower text , Add. 17,136, foll. 124-125, 128, 130-132, 135-136, 138, 140, 142-143, 147-148, and 150-151, lower text , Add. 17,136, foll. 118, 123, 133, 141, 145, and 149, lower text , and Add. 17,136, fol. 146, lower text ). Foll. 119, 121, 122, 127, 129, 134, and 144, do not present any traces of being palimpsest.

handNote.desc: This manuscript, large portions of which are palimpsest, is written in a rather inelegant, current hand of the xth or xith cent.
The first 15 leaves are of somewhat later date.

decoNote.desc: There are a considerable number of small ornamental devices in this volume, coloured with red, yellow and green paints.

item.p: According to a note on fol. 105 a, this manuscript was written at Ḳūnia, or Iconium, by one Abraham Malīh:

msItem.title: Extracts from Ephraim
msItem.quote: ܕܝܠܗ ܕ[ܡܪܝ]ܐܦܪܝܡ̣ ܡـ[ـܢ ܫ]ܪܒܐ ܕܥܠ ܗ̇ܝ ܕܐܡܠܟ ܡܘܬܐ ܡܢ ܐܕܡ ܥܕܡܐ ܠܡܘܫܐ

item.p: Vellum, about 5 3/8 in. by 4. These folia are double palimpsest (see Add. 17,136, foll. 1-151, upper text 2 and Add. 17,136, foll. 117 and 126, lower text ).

handNote.desc: Over the lower text, a Syrian scribe of the ixth cent. has written selections from several authors.

msItem.title: Portions of the Gospel of S. John
msItem.note: See Tischendorf, Monumm. Sacra Inedita, Nova Collectio, vol. ii., p. xiii. and pp. 311, 312.

msItem.title: The Gospel of S. John, ch. xiii., vv. 16, 17, 19, 20, 23, 24, 26, and 27
he Gospel of S. John, ch. xvi. vv. 7, 8, 12, 13, 15, 16, 18, and 19

item.p: Vellum, about 5 3/8 in. by 4. Two leaves from a Greek manuscript of the Gospel of S. John, written in double columns. These folia are double palimpsest (see Add. 17,136, foll. 1-151, upper text 2 and Add. 17,136, foll. 117 and 126, upper text 1 ).

handNote.desc: These leaves are written in elegant uncials of the ivth or vth cent.

msItem.title: Liturgical contents
msItem.note: The contents appear to be liturgical (see foll. 145 b and 149 a).

handNote.desc: These leaves are written in a neat, small Estrangela of about the viiith cent.

item.p: Vellum, about 5 3/8 in. by 4. Three dipalimpsest leaves (see Add. 17,136, foll. 1-151, upper text 2 and Add. 17,136, foll. 120, 137, and 139, lower text ). Both of the ancient texts are Syriac, written in two columns.

handNote.desc: These leaves are written in a small character of the viiith or ixth cent.

bibl.author: William Wright
bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

interpretation.p: Description is based on Wright's Catalogue without consultation of physical manuscripts. Foliation is approximate. Wright often does not indicate ending folia so those have been assumed based on beginning folia.
Scribal notes which could not be more clearly classified based on Wright's descriptions have been identified as <addition>s whether they occur in the margins or the body of the manuscript.
In general, we have classified as an <msItem> as much of the manuscript contents as possible, including tables of contents and indices.
